A polynomial with coefficients in a field or ring is defined as a formal sum $f=\sum_{j=0}^{n} a_{j} X^{j}$, where $a_{j}$ are the coefficients. This definition emphasizes that a polynomial is identified with the sequence of its coefficients.

A normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. It is a prestage to Galois extensions. An algebraic field extension \\(K \subset L\\) is called normal if it satisfies the equivalent conditions of Theorem 4: (i) Every \\(K\\)-homomorphism \\(L \longrightarrow \bar{L}\\) into an algebraic closure \\(\bar{L}\\) of \\(L\\) restricts to an automorphism of \\(L\\). (ii) \\(L\\) is a splitting field of a family of polynomials in \\(K[X]\\). (iii) Every irreducible polynomial in \\(K[X]\\) that admits a zero in \\(L\\) decomposes over \\(L\\) completely into linear factors.
Does the concept of a/an Polynomial need to be defined for a definition of a/an Normal field extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a normal field extension explicitly references the concept of a polynomial. It states that a normal field extension is an extension field that is the splitting field of a family of polynomials from the base field. Additionally, it mentions that the field extension is normal if it is a splitting field for a family of polynomials in \(K[X]\), where \(K[X]\) denotes the ring of polynomials with coefficients in the base field \(K\). Furthermore, it also states that every irreducible polynomial in \(K[X]\) that has a zero in \(L\) must decompose completely into linear factors over \(L\). Thus, the concept of a polynomial is integral to understanding what constitutes a normal field extension, as polynomials are used to define the conditions under which an extension field is considered normal.
